title: Technical Modules
text:
Technical lessons aim to teach and practice a specific data science tool. The format generally combines lecture to introduce concepts, live coding and optional hand-on practice sessions. Here we provide a list with a short description of our current technical offerings. The specific goals of each of these lessons can be adapted to best fit your team and meet all participants where they are. If you are interested in a topic that is not on this list, please let us know and we are happy to discuss the feasibility of creating new materials.
For all of these lessons participants will need a computer with recent versions of R and RStudio installed. Check out instructions to install or upgrade R and RStudio here.






    
      
      
    










Cleaning and Wrangling Data



beginner


data wrangling






















Collaborating using Git and GitHub & Merge Conflicts



intermediate

intermediate

title: Non-Technical Modules
text:
As part of our comprehensive approach to open data science best practices, in addition to helping you built and practice your technical skills, we also offer non-technical lessons. These modules range from interactive activities to discussion-based lesson, mixing briefing of information with practical tips and exercises.
Most of these lessons can be delivered in person during your visit to NCEAS or remote. Some particular lessons only can be offered in-person. The modality of the lesson is stated in each lesson’s description.














Data Modeling Essentials



tidy data






















LEGO® Reproducibility Activity



activity


reproducibility






















Metadata Best Practices



data management






















Reproducibility and Provenance



reproducibility






















The FAIR and CARE Principles



data ethics






















Thinking Preferences



activity


team science






















Writing Data Management Plans



data management
















No matching items

title: Introduction to programming in R using RStudio
text: New to R? This lesson walks through the basic concepts of the R programming language.

title: Introduction to programming in R using RStudio
text:
Description
This lesson is a gentle introduction to working with R using the RStudio interface. The goal is to become familiarize with how the R language works as the starting point to learn more in depth technique to advance your science.

title: Introduction to programming in R using RStudio
text:
Prerequisites
None

title: Introduction to programming in R using RStudio
text:
Learning Goals

Get familiarize with RStudio interface
Learn the basics of R syntax (functions, packages, objects, vectors, assignment operator)
Understand the difference between a script and the console
Create and inspect vectors, identifying their class, content and structure
Read and inspect data in R and understand the data structure
Apply basic mathematical operations with values in a data table

title: Introduction to programming in R using RStudio
text:
Duration
2 hours

title: Collaborating using Git and GitHub & Merge Conflicts
text: Git and GitHub streamlines collaboration on a reseach project by allowing everyone working on a project to work simultaneously, share work, and tag specific challenges or questions for each other.

title: Collaborating using Git and GitHub & Merge Conflicts
text:
Description
Git is a great tool for working on your own, but even better for working with friends and colleagues. Git allows you to work with confidence on your own local copy of files with the confidence that you will be able to successfully synchronize your changes with the changes made by others. This lesson presents step-by-step how to start collaborating with colleagues avoiding conflicts. It also walks you through what can cause a merge conflict, how to solve a merge conflict and thing to consider to avoid conflicts in general.

title: Collaborating using Git and GitHub & Merge Conflicts
text:
Prerequisites

Introduction to Git and GitHub lesson (or be familiar with content of lesson)

title: Collaborating using Git and GitHub & Merge Conflicts
text:
Learnig Goal

Introduce how to use Git and GitHub to collaborate with colleagues on code
Revise what typically causes conflicts when collaborating
Demonstrate and practice how to resolve a conflict
Descibe workflows to avoid conflicts

title: Collaborating using Git and GitHub & Merge Conflicts
text:
Duration
2 hours

title: Cleaning and Wrangling Data
text: To be efficient analysts, we should have good tools to wrangle data to fit our needs. This way we can do further work like making plots and fitting models.

title: Cleaning and Wrangling Data
text:
Description
This lesson aims to provide tools for reformatting data too meet your analysis needs. In general, the data we get to work with is not in the format we need to do our analyses. The dplyr and tidyr R packages provide a fairly complete and extremely powerful set of functions for us to do this reformatting quickly. Learning these tools well will greatly increase your efficiency as an analyst.

title: Cleaning and Wrangling Data
text:
Prerequisites

Basic knowledge about R and RStudio.
If you are new to R consider taking our Intro to programming in R using RStudio lesson.

title: Cleaning and Wrangling Data
text:
Learning Goals

Understand the basics of data wrangling conceptually
Introduce dplyr and tidyr functions to clean and wrangle data for analysis
Learn about the pipe operator as a tool to pass on argument(s) through a sequence of - functions
Describe the difference between wide vs. long table formats and how to convert between them

title: Cleaning and Wrangling Data
text:
Duration
2 hours

title: Literate Analysis with Quarto
text: Combine prose and code in one document! Literate analysis is a fundamental tool for making your work reproducible.

title: Literate Analysis with Quarto
text:
Description
More often than not computational analysis is written in a way that is borderline incomprehensible even to the person who originally wrote the code. Quarto is a tool that allows you to combine prose with code. This way be able to do analysis and write reports all in one place. This course introduces the concept of literate analysis and explores the main functionalities of a Quarto document combining R, the programming language, and markdown, a set of text formatting directives.

title: Literate Analysis with Quarto
text:
Prerequisites

Basic knowledge about R and RStudio.
If you are new to R consider taking our Intro to programming in R using RStudio lesson.

title: Literate Analysis with Quarto
text:
Learning Goals

Introduce Quarto as a tool for literate analysis
Learn markdown syntax and run R code in Quarto
Understand the “environments” and file paths when working with Quarto documents

title: Literate Analysis with Quarto
text:
Duration
2 hours

title: Creating Functions in R
text: Take your coding skills to the next level by incorporating your own functions in your analysis.

title: Creating Functions in R
text:
Description
Functions allow you to break your code into small, resusbale modules. In this lesson, we will review the advantages of coding with functions, practice by creating some functions and show how to call them, and then do some exercises to build other simple functions.

title: Creating Functions in R
text:
Prerequisites

Intermediate R and RStudio user
Basic understanding of ggplo2

title: Creating Functions in R
text:
Learning Goals

Learn why we should write code in small functions
Write code for one or more functions
Document functions to improve understanding and code communication

title: Creating Functions in R
text:
Duration
1 hour

title: Introduction to Data Visualization
text: Data visualization is a great tool to explore communicate about your data. Learn the basics of visualizing your data with ggplot2 and other data vis packages.

title: Introduction to Data Visualization
text:
Description
ggplot is a popular and powerful package for visualizing data in R. The goal of this lesson is to introduce you to the basic components of working with ggplot2 and inspire you to keep exploring this package. We also briefly introduce the leaflet and dt package as a way to create interactive maps and tables respectively.

title: Introduction to Data Visualization
text:
Prerequisites

Basic knowledge about R and RStudio
Familiarity with the packages dyplr and tidyr

title: Introduction to Data Visualization
text:
Learning Goals

Introduce the basics of the ggplot2 package to create static plots
Understand how to use ggplot2’s theme abilities to create publication-grade graphics
Learn the basics of the leaflet package to create interactive maps

title: Introduction to Data Visualization
text:
Duration
2 hours

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text: Benefit from Git and GitHub’s power to facilitate collaborative research and code management practices.

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text:
Description
Every file in the scientific process changes. Manuscripts are edited. Figures get revised. Code gets fixed when bugs are discovered. These changes are important to track, and yet, we often use simplistic filenames to track them. Is there a better way? YES, version control. Version control provides an organized and transparent way to track changes in code and additional files. Git is a version control software and GitHub is website that allows users to store their Git repositories and share them with others. This lesson is a friendly introduction to these tools. It explains the main concepts and walks you through the Git and GitHub workflow using RStudio.

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text:
Prerequisites

Familiarity with R and RStudio
Have a GitHub account (sign up at github.com)
Have Git installed in your computer (see instructions here)

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text:
Learnig Goal

Apply the principles of Git to track and manage changes of a project
Utilize the Git workflow including pulling changes, staging modified files, committing changes, pulling again to incorporate remote changes, and pushing changes to a remote repository
Create and configure Git repositories using different workflows

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text:
Duration
2 hours

title: Creating R Packages
text: Package your work and share it! Creating your own package allows you to organize your code and data in a way that easily be shared and reused.

title: Creating R Packages
text:
Description
Most R users are familiar with loading and utilizing packages in their work. However have never created a package of their own. Creating packages serves two main use cases:

Mechanism to redistribute reusable code (even if just for yourself)
Mechanism to reproducibly document analysis and models and their results

This lesson will walk you a simple example for creating and documenting an R package. The goal is to demystify the complexity of this tool and encourage you and you collaborators to create a package as you see fit.

title: Creating R Packages
text:
Prerequisites

Intermediate R and RStudio user

##Learning Goals - Learn about the advantages of using R packages for organizing code - Implement simple techniques for creating R packages - Introduce approaches to documenting code in packages

title: Creating R Packages
text:
Duration
1 hour

title: Using sf for Spatial Data
text: Handling spatial data can be tricky. The sf package allow for integration of R spatial software with the tidyverse if desired.

title: Using sf for Spatial Data
text:
Description
The sf package in R implements simple features, a standard that describes how spatial geometry objects in the real world can be represented in computers. This lesson will walk you through using sf functions to work with spatial data and create extraordinary maps.

title: Using sf for Spatial Data
text:
Prerequisites

Intermediate R and RStudio user
Familiarity with the packages dyplr, tidyr and ggplot2

title: Using sf for Spatial Data
text:
Learning Goals

Understand how to use the sf package to wrangle spatial data
Introduce static mapping with ggplot
Create customized interactive maps with leaflet

title: Using sf for Spatial Data
text:
Duration
2 hours

title: Reproducible Data Access
text: Accesing data is the first step to any analysis. Being able to do this in a portable is the ultimate goal to make your work as reproducible as possible.

title: Reproducible Data Access
text:
Description
Traditional ways of working with data – as files on a specific computer – limit the reproducibility of code to local compute environments. A typical R analysis file will load one or many data files from the local disk. However, it is rarely the case that those file paths work on your colleague’s machine. Alternatively we can access data through the Internet with a URL. But what happens if the URL to the data changes? (Which they often do). This lesson teaches you about pins and content identifiers and how to use them to access your data in a robust reproducible way.

title: Reproducible Data Access
text:
Prerequisites

Be familiar with R and RStudio

title: Reproducible Data Access
text:
Learnig Goal

Best practices for reproducible data access
Accessing data on the web and with pins
How content identifiers differ from DOIs and make research more reproducible
Ways to register and resolve content identifiers for unpublished data
How content identifiers can resolve to published data source

title: Reproducible Data Access
text:
Duration
1 hour

title: Working with text data in R
text: Apply data wrangling and data visualization methods to text and make text mining easier, more effective and consistent.

title: Working with text data in R
text:
Description
Text mining is the process by which unstructured text is transformed into a structured format to prepare it for analysis. The goal of this lesson is to introduce tools that allow us to move from unstructured text to a structured format to perform analysis.

title: Working with text data in R
text:
Prerequisites

Basic knowledge about R and RStudio
Familiarity with the packages dyplr, tidyr and ggplot2

title: Working with text data in R
text:
Learning Goals

Describe what is a token and how they are used
Demonstrate how to use stop words
Create customize stop words
Provide tools to give structure to unstructured text

title: Working with text data in R
text:
Duration
2 hours

title: Introduction to Shiny
text: Shiny apps provide interactive features for letting others share and explore data and analyses.

title: Introduction to Shiny
text:
Description
Shiny is an R package for creating interactive data visualizations embedded in a web application that you and your colleagues can view with just a web browser. The goal of this lesson is to learn about the Shiny architecture and build a sample Shiny app to deploy interactive visualizations.

title: Introduction to Shiny
text:
Prerequisites

Intermediate level R user
Familiarity with ggplot2

title: Introduction to Shiny
text:
Learning Goals

Review the capabilities in Shiny applications
Learn about the basic layout for Shiny interfaces
Learn about the server component for Shiny applications
Build a simple shiny application for interactive plotting

title: Introduction to Shiny
text:
Duration
3 hours

title: Reproducible Papers
text: Take reproducibility to the next level. Pack all the elements of your research into one container so future you and others can reproduce your work.

title: Reproducible Papers
text:
Description
Under the reproducible umbrella, this lesson aims to provide tools and a framework for writing reproducible papers. The idea is to leverage on different R packages that can help you organize your research from start to finish. Particularly focusing on formatting publication manuscripts for specific journal.

title: Reproducible Papers
text:
Prerequisites

Basic knowledge about R and RStudio
Familiarity with Rmarkdown and/or Quarto

title: Reproducible Papers
text:
Learning Goals

Introduce the concept of reserach compendium
Learn how to use R to package your work by building a reproducible paper in RMarkdown/Quarto

title: Reproducible Papers
text:
Duration
1 hour

title: Publishing to the Web using GitHub Pages
text: Tools like Quarto, RMarkdown, and GitHub allows you to share your work with others in a beautiful and easy to read web page.

title: Publishing to the Web using GitHub Pages
text:
Description
Sharing your work with others in engaging ways is an important part of the scientific process. This lesson shows you how to turn a GitHub repository into a webpage to easily share your analysis, code, and writing with others.

title: Publishing to the Web using GitHub Pages
text:
Prerequisites

Have a GitHub account (you can sign up at github.com)
Familiarity with GitHub (consider taking Introduction to Git and GitHub)
Be comfortable using R and RStudio

title: Publishing to the Web using GitHub Pages
text:
Learnig Goal

Practice how to use Git, GitHub (+Pages), and R Markdown or Quarto to publish an analysis to the web

title: Publishing to the Web using GitHub Pages
text:
Duration
30 min

title: Metadata Best Practices
text: Metadata is the data about your data. Having an organized and detailed metadata is key for reprodcucibility and reuse of your data.

title: Metadata Best Practices
text:
Description
Within the data life cycle you can be collecting data (creating new data) or integrating data that has all ready been collected. Either way, metadata plays a major role to successfully spin around the cycle because it enables data reuse long after the original collection. This lesson walks through guidelines and best practices that will help you organize the documentation of your data.

title: Metadata Best Practices
text:
Prerequisites
None

title: Metadata Best Practices
text:
Learnig Goal

Understand metadata guidelines and best practices for reproducibility
Introduce useful metadata standards within the environmental/ecology field

title: Metadata Best Practices
text:
Duration
30 min

title: The FAIR and CARE Principles
text: These principles aim to make data available to machines, researchers, Indigenous communities, policy makers, and more.

title: The FAIR and CARE Principles
text:
Description
The idea behind these principles is to increase access and usage of complex and large datasets for innovation, discovery, and decision-making. This lessons reviews each of these principles providing examples on how to out them in practice when working with data. This module mixes briefing of content, discussion and exercises for participants to evaluate these principles with real data.

title: The FAIR and CARE Principles
text:
Prerequisites
None

title: The FAIR and CARE Principles
text:
Learnig Goal

Introduce FAIR and CARE principles and the value it provides to data
Provide a FAIR and CARE lens that can be applied to your data-focused work
Evaluate the FAIRness and CAREness of your work and the work of others

title: The FAIR and CARE Principles
text:
Duration
1 hours

title: Data Modeling Essentials
text: Following best practices to format data tables allows us to manage and analyze data efficiently.

title: Data Modeling Essentials
text:
Description
Preparing your data for analysis can me time consuming and tedious. But, it is a necessary step before analyzing your data. This lesson dives deep into what is tidy and normalize data and how make sure your data structure follow a “tidy structure”. It also introduces relational data models and provides an overview of merging data using joins. This lesson explores fundamentals concepts for working with data and includes a hands on exercise to apply these concepts to a real data set.

title: Data Modeling Essentials
text:
Prerequisites
None

title: Data Modeling Essentials
text:
Learnig Goal

Applying tidy and normalized data principles
Following best practices to format data tables’ content
Relating tables following relational data models principles
Understanding how to perform table joins.

title: Data Modeling Essentials
text:
Duration
2 hours

title: Reproducibility and Provenance
text: Reproducible workflows increase research effcicinecy, accelerates collaboration and increase trust in science.

title: Reproducibility and Provenance
text:
Description
In most cases the methods sections of papers are inadequate to fully reproduce the work described in the paper. By looking at a figure on a paper we don’t get the full story how did the scientist got to make this plot. This lesson introduces de concepts of computational reproducibility and provenance and gives an overview on how they can be achieved in your work.

title: Reproducibility and Provenance
text:
Prerequisites
None

title: Reproducibility and Provenance
text:
Learnig Goal

Discuss the concept of reproducible workflows including computational reproducibility and provenance metadata
Introduce tools and techniques for reproducibility supported by the NCEAS and DataONE

title: Reproducibility and Provenance
text:
Duration
30 min

title: Writing Data Management Plans
text: Documenting your project using a thorough data management plan it’s an important step to achiving a reproducible open science framework for your research.

title: Writing Data Management Plans
text:
Description
Successfully managing your data throughout a research project helps ensures its preservation for future use. Having an organize data management plan allows your research outcomes to be transparent, maximizing the effective use and value of your work. This lesson provides an overview of all that needs to be in place for writing an effective data management plan and introduces tools that can help you organize and keep track of this information.

title: Writing Data Management Plans
text:
Prerequisites
None

title: Writing Data Management Plans
text:
Learnig Goal

State the importance of creating data management plans
Explain the major components of data management plans
Recommend tools that can help create a data management plan
Provide features and functionality of the DMPTool

title: Writing Data Management Plans
text:
Duration
1 hour

title: LEGO® Reproducibility Activity
text: Get together in teams and build a lego structure and document the process as you go. Fun and interactive icebreaker activity to introduce the concept of reproducibility.

title: LEGO® Reproducibility Activity
text:
Description
This is an interactive activity where participants have to build a structure using LEGO®. The challenge part comes when it comes documenting the process so others can replicate what you built. This activity is a great icebreaker to get everyone talking about the importance of clear documentation for reproducible workflows.

title: LEGO® Reproducibility Activity
text:
Prerequisites

None

title: LEGO® Reproducibility Activity
text:
Learnig Goal

Illustrate elements of good reproducibility through the medium of LEGO®
Discuss what is needed and what is not needed for good reproducibility

title: LEGO® Reproducibility Activity
text:
Duration
1 hours

title: Thinking Preferences
text: Undertsanding how people think and process information helps us understand not only our own approach to problem solving, but also how individuals within a team can contribute.

title: Thinking Preferences
text:
Description
Everyone thinks differently. The way individuals think guides the way they work, and the way groups of individuals think guides how teams work. Understanding thinking preferences facilitates effective collaboration and team work. This module is an interactive activity that allows you to get to know about different thinking styles and how each type brings strengths to different aspects of project.

title: Thinking Preferences
text:
Prerequisites
None

title: Thinking Preferences
text:
Learnig Goal

Get to know fellow participants and how they think.
Discuss about the Whole Brain Thinking System as a helpful tool understand different approaches to problem solving.

title: Thinking Preferences
text:
Duration
30 to 45 min
In person only

title: NCEAS Learning Hub Data Science Modules
text:
NCEAS’ Learning Hub is exited to offer Data Science training opportunities to synthesis working groups.
NCEAS is a leading expert on interdisciplinary data science and works collaboratively to answer the world’s largest and most complex questions. The NCEAS approach leverages existing data and employs a team science philosophy to squeeze out all potential insights and solutions efficiently - this is called synthesis science.
With over 25 years of experience working with working groups and environmental professionals, NCEAS wants to make sure to along skills, workflows, mindsets for successfully doing synthesis science.

title: NCEAS Learning Hub Data Science Modules
text:
This Site
Here you can find the description and requirement for all of the data science modules currently available in our curriculum. We offer variety of data science training, from technical to non-technical skills, beginners and intermediate users.
The idea is for your team to decide which skills would be more helpful to learn to advance you science. Then we work together to schedule one or more workshops and make sure you can successfully apply these new skills to your project.

title: NCEAS Learning Hub Data Science Modules
text:
Why learn this tools?
[mention something about reproducibility and better science in less time]

title: Introductory Level
text: Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see https://quarto.org.

title: Introductory Level
text:
Running Code
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

1 + 1

[1] 2


You can add options to executable code like this


[1] 4


The echo: false option disables the printing of code (only output is displayed).
